awd_titl_txt: Exponential Periods, Bispectrality and Affine Quantum Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of symmetry is a basic paradigm in science, with fundamental consequences for crystallography, particle physics, general relativity, quantum computing and signal processing. The study of the (bilateral, translation, rotational, scaling and other) symmetries of a given chemical, physical or mathematical system is often key to its understanding, and ultimate solution, since their presence greatly constrains the system. Quantum groups are deformations of the most basic symmetries of Nature. They were discovered in the 1980s as symmetries of one and two-dimensional statistical mechanical models that describe, for example, thin layers of ice. Quantum groups have re-emerged very recently as the symmetries of four-dimensional gauge theories that describe the interaction of elementary particles such as quarks. 

Quantum groups form a hierarchy that depends on the strength of the deformation and their dependence on a spectral parameter: constant, rational, trigonometric or elliptic. As the hierarchical level rises, an interesting trade-off occurs: some of the structure becomes far more intricate, while some simplifies radically. This project will further uncover relations that exist between different members of the hierarchy by building conceptual bridges between them. These conceptual bridges will have fundamental consequences for the quantum groups they link. On the one hand, they will give a radically simpler description of the multivaluedness of the differential or difference equations for one quantum group in terms of its hierarchical superior. On the other, they will give a self-contained description of the latter in terms of the former which, in addition to clarifying its structure, has potentially far reaching arithmetic consequences. More precisely, the present project will explore the relations between affine quantum groups. One main theme of the project is to extend the description of the monodromy of the rational Casimir connection of a symmetrisable Kac-Moody algebra, in terms of quantum Weyl group operators, to numerical values of the deformation parameter, and to the difference analogue of the connection. The second main theme of the project is to use the meromorphic tensor equivalence of finite dimensional representations of Yangians and quantum loop algebras, and of quantum loop algebras and elliptic quantum groups, to compute the monodromy of the trigonomeric Casimir connection and of the rational and trigonometric qKZ equations, thus proving the difference analog of the Drinfeld-Kohno theorem conjectured by Frenkel and Reshetikhin.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum groups were discovered in the 80s in the mathematical study of phase transition, the transformation of one state of matter (solid, liquid, gas) to another. They have since spurred a tremendous number of profound advances in seemingly very disparate areas in Mathematics and Theoretical Physics: representation theory (the mathematical study of symmetry), topology (the study of shape), algebraic geometry (the study of curves and surfaces defined by polynomial equations, and their higher dimensional analogues), statistical mechanics (the understanding of macroscopic properties of matter from its microscopic description), gauge theory (which describes the most elementary constituents of matter such as quarks), string theory, and quantum computing.

  This project results in four distinct advances in the study of quantum groups.

The first advance is the determination of the multivaluedness of solutions of differential equations in the complex domain known as the Casimir equation in terms of quantum groups. This was carried out in collaboration with Andrea Appel, a former graduate student and NSF funded Research Assistant of the PI. It caps a long term joint research effort begun in 2009, and supported through several NSF grants. One of the outcomes of this program is to precisely relate Lie groups, which describe the symmetries of macroscopic physical systems, and quantum groups, which describe the symmetries of microscopic ones.

The second advance settled a very long standing conjecture concerning a quantum group called the Yangian, after the 1957 Nobel Prize Physicist C. N. Yang. It is endowed with a universal R-matrix, a fundamental structure in the statistical mechanical models for which the Yangian is an algebra of symmetries. Though it was known since the 80s that the R-matrix of the Yangian was given by a divergent series (a series which a priori cannot be summed, such as 1-1+1-…), Drinfeld (one of the 1986 Fields Medalists) has proved that in a number of important cases, that series  could be modified to yield a rational function of the temperature parameter. This project uncovered a different procedure, known in analysis as resummation (for example the resummation of 1-1+1-.. is 1/2), which  yielded an analytic function of that parameter in all cases. The project was carried out with Sachin Gautam, a former PhD student of the PI, who is currently an Assistant Professor at Ohio State University, and Curtis Wendlandt, a postdoctoral researcher mentored by S. Gautam, who has since been hired as an Assistant Professor at the University of Saskatchewan.

The third advance ties several strands together: quantum groups, their geometric counterparts which are known as Poisson-Lie groups, and Stokes phenomena. The latter are a fascinating aspect of certain differential equations for which the solutions are not entirely captured by the recursive, and often programmable method used to solve them. The missing information, or Stokes data, can be considered as a hidden symmetry of the differential equation, as they relate different solutions possessing the same formal expansions. Around 2000’s P. Boalch, a mathematician working in Paris discovered that Poisson Lie groups govern the Stokes data of a class of such equations. This project established a quantum analogue of this link: quantum groups govern the Stokes phenomena of a class of differential equations called the Knizhnik-Zamolodchikov equations, which were discovered in String Theory in the 80s. It was carried out in collaboration with Xiaomeng Xu, an Assistant Professor at Beijing University.

The fourth advance settles a 10-year old conjecture formulated by M. Finkelberg and V. Ginzburg, two mathematicians working in Moscow and Chicago respectively. This conjecture describes the monodromy of a system of differential equations in terms of a a quantum group known as the trigonometric Cherednik algebra. The project gave a precise determination of this monodromy for all values of the parameters. It shows in particular that, contrary to general expectations, the FG conjecture fails  for special values of these parameters. This project was carried out in collaboration with Robin Walters, an NSF postdoctoral fellow mentored by the PI, who was subsequently hired as an Assistant Professor in Computer Science at Northeastern University.
